content.webTitle: Letters: California's battle over Kyoto pledge

fields.headline: California's battle over Kyoto pledge
fields.bodyText: Your report that foreign polluters are donating money to support US politicians hostile to action to fight climate change is depressing, but highlighting California's proposition 19 rather than proposition 23 is surprising (Foreign firms are major donors to Tea Party, 25 October). In 2006, California enacted a law referred to as AB32, a landmark environmental law that establishes a timetable to bring California into near compliance with the Kyoto protocol by reducing greenhouse gas emissions to their 1990 levels by 2020. Proposition 23 is a proposal to "suspend" the AB32 provisions until unemployment in the state falls to the level it was when the law was introduced and stays there for a year. The proposition uses a clever ploy: it blames the clean-air laws for the state's economic woes, not the banking collapse, and puts a removal condition in place that makes it unknowable as to when, if ever, the "suspension" will be revoked. Such conditions are anathema to investors. Venture capitalists are not reckless: they need to be able to calculate the risk level they face. Calculating that risk level is made easier by having a legislative background that is transparent, long-lasting and clear. As far as I can ascertain, this is the first time that people anywhere have been given the chance to vote simply on whether to go back to pollution. How Californians vote could have a global impact: California's economy is, in effect, the 7th largest in the world. Proposition 23 is mainly financed by two Texan oil companies that have refineries in the state and is opposed by a broad alliance under the banner of stopdirtyenergyprop.com. The committee cannot accept donations from non-US nationals, but it can be supported through social media. Polls suggest that voters' intentions are finely balanced, so there is a real possibility for individuals to make a real difference through taking action. Harold Forbes Author, How to be a Humankind Superhero
